title: High Street faces £137m hike in business rates despite shops closing
text:
The struggling High Street must shoulder another £137million in business rates from April.

It will take the total paid by the sector to £6.25billion after a year when dozens of famous names have gone bust or closed stores.

The total increase for all sectors in England will be £536million, handing the Treasury an estimated £25billion for England.

Familiar sight: Shops closed down at a rate of 16 per day in the first half of this year, prompting calls for business rates reform

Retailers account for 5 per cent of the economy, but pay a quarter of all business rates, says the British Retail Consortium.

The Daily Mail has been campaigning for business rates reform to give shops some relief and protect Britain's high streets.

Shops closed down at a rate of 16 per day in the first half of this year.

Office Outlet, formerly known as Staples, went bust in March, followed by celebrity chef Jamie Oliver's restaurant chain in May.

Household names such as Marks & Spencer, Debenhams and Topshop owner Arcadia are closing stores.

Dominic Curran, property policy adviser at the British Retail Consortium, said: 'This £137million increase will reduce the ability of retailers to invest in their business, their staff and their shops.

'The Chancellor must take action on rates in the forthcoming Budget.'
